payload.question: Gender Identity
payload.answer: Gender identity refers to how we feel about our own gender and how we would like other to see us in temrs of our own gender, which may or may not be correspond to the sex assigned to us at birth. It refers to each person's deeply felt internal and individual experience of gender and includes the personal sense of body and other expressions, such as dress, speech and mannerisms.

payload.question: Sex
payload.answer: Boys and girls are born with a variety of physical differences, in term of their bodies. A person's sex (male/female) is decided by these physical differences e.g. (boys and girls have different genitalia, girls enter the phase of puberty before boys etc.)

payload.question: GBV
payload.answer: The phrase gender-based violence is used to describe hurtful or unwanted acts that a person experiences because of their gender or gender identity. These acts can involve physical violence (punching, slapping, kicking, pushing), the use of hurtful words, unwanted touching and attention, teasing, bullying or leaving someone out of a game/conversation on purpose because of their gender or gender identity.

payload.question: Gender
payload.answer: The words gender and sex are often used as though they mean the same thing. But it is important to say that these two words do not mean the same thing. Gender refers to the socially-constructed set of expectation, behaviour and activities of women and men which are attributed to them on the basis of their sex. A person's gender is decided by three parts: a person's physical body, a person's gender identity (how they view themselves and feel about their own gender) and the way a person behaves with other people and how they would like to be viewed by others.

payload.question: Gender Stereotype
payload.answer:
A gender stereotype can be described as an unfair and untrue belief that many people have about all people of a certain gender identity. Examples of gender stereotypes include:
 1) All boys enjoy sports (this is inaccurate as many boys prefer to engage in activities such as painting, music or drama and have little intereset in sport).
 2) Girls' favourite toys are dolls(This is not true as girls enhoy a whole range of different toys such as action figues, teddies or toy trains or cars.)
 All of us should be free from gender stereotypes and be able to choose whom they want to be.
